Award.AwardTitle: Gas in the Planet-Forming Region of Circumstellar Disks: Exploiting the Mid-IR Molecular Forest
Award.AbstractNarration: Dr. Blake and his team study the chemistry and physics of the innermost regions (0.5-50 AU) of very young circumstellar disks. The project uses of ground-based (Keck-NIRSPEC, VLT-CRIRES, Gemini-MICHELLE) spectroscopy and spectro-astrometry of accretion disks. The rovibrational line emissions of the molecules CO, HCN, C2H2, H2O, OH, and other molecules are used to constrain the physical and chemical structure and evolution of the protoplanetary disks' inner regions. These observations are interpreted with 2D (axisymetric) and 3D radiative transfer models. In order to derive accurate molecular abundances, the group will extend their radiative transfer codes to generate non-local thermodynamic equilibrium level populations relevant for IR transitions. Further studies are planned for the outer disks using far IR and submm lines from Herschel and potentially ALMA. The project provides training for a PhD student and postdoc.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research program investigated the behavior of what chemists and astronomers call 'volatiles' in the circumstellar accretion disks that encircle young stars. These disks are the birthplace of planets, and key volatiles such as water, carbon monoxide, methane, ammonia, molecular nitrogen, and the like are thought to play important roles in the initiation of the planet-building process from small grains of dust and ice, and may well be critical to the delivery of life-enabling elements such as carbon and nitrogen in the forms and time scales needed to render terrestrial planets habitable.

In particular, we used a combination of observations from infrared telescopes in space and on the ground with those taken at much longer wavelengths - in the radio to millimeter-wave region of the electromagnetic spectrum - to study key volatiles in disks. Studies at these wavelengths can pierce the large amounts of scattering due to small particles - such as exists in clouds in the sky, for example - to study key volatiles. Key to the longest wavelength studies were early shared risk observations with the Atacama Large Millimeter Array (ALMA) in northern Chile, a new facility that is transforming our view of the Universe and our place in it.

Via these studies, we have located the water ice (snow) line for the first time in protoplanetary disks, and have compared the observed locations to estimates of the snow line location in the solar system. In particular, we find - as expected - that the snow line at late times in the disk is interior to that seen inferred for the asteroid belt, which has implications for the organic chemistry in materials that build terrestrial planets. We have also determined the location of the carbon monoxide frost line, a key reservior of carbon and a location that may influence the composition of comets and other icy bodies formed in the outer solar system.

Finally, we have also used the tools developed as part of this research to remotely detect the atmospheres of non-transiting extrasolar planets for the first time. The composition of these atmospheres may tell us a great deal about where in the disks such planets formed.

The graduate students who have driven this research have been significantly involved in education and public outreach initiatives at Caltech and more broadly, and have moved on to permanent positions and careers in science education and science policy.
